benchmark_details.name: CASS (CUDA–AMD ASsembly and Source Mapping)
benchmark_details.overview: CASS is the first large-scale dataset for GPU code transpilation, containing 70k semantically aligned Nvidia ↔AMD pairs at both the source (CUDA ↔HIP) and assembly levels (SASS ↔RDNA3), covering 16 real-world GPU domains.

purpose_and_intended_users.goal: To address the lack of cross-architecture GPU translation datasets and to validate the effectiveness of GPU code transpilation models.
purpose_and_intended_users.limitations: Current performance is inadequate for production due to limited accuracy in complex or underrepresented domains. The dataset only covers one host/device pair per vendor.

data.source: The dataset is constructed from verified CUDA and HIP code pairs, along with their corresponding assembly representations.
data.annotation: Manually verified to compile and run successfully

methodology.calculation: Accuracy is calculated based on the percentage of successful translations compared to ground-truth outputs.
methodology.interpretation: Higher accuracy indicates better performance in translating GPU code across different architectures.
methodology.baseline_results: Achieved 95% accuracy in source translation and 37.5% in assembly translation.
methodology.validation: The dataset and models were validated against real-world execution scenarios.

ethical_and_legal_considerations.data_licensing: All data, models, and evaluation tools are released as open source.
